Rouché's theorem

Let Ω⊆C\Omega \subseteq \CΩ⊆C be open and connected. Suppose {fn}n\set{f_n}_n{fn​}n​ is a sequence of injective holomorphic functions defined on Ω\OmegaΩ, such that fn→ff_n \to ffn​→f locally uniformly in Ω\OmegaΩ. Show that if fff is not constant, then fff is also injective in Ω\OmegaΩ.
Solution.

Suppose fff were not injective, so there exist z1≠z2z_1 \neq z_2z1​=z2​ in Ω\OmegaΩ such that w=f(z1)=f(z2)w = f\p{z_1} = f\p{z_2}w=f(z1​)=f(z2​). Since Ω\OmegaΩ is connected, there exists a path γ\gammaγ such that γ(0)=z1\gamma\p{0} = z_1γ(0)=z1​ and γ(1)=z2\gamma\p{1} = z_2γ(1)=z2​.

Let δ=12d(γ,Ωc)>0\delta = \frac{1}{2}d\p{\gamma, \Omega^\comp} > 0δ=21​d(γ,Ωc)>0 and cover C\CC with squares with side length δ\deltaδ. Let Ωγ\Omega_\gammaΩγ​ be the union of the squares which intersect γ\gammaγ non-trivially, and by our choice of δ\deltaδ, we see that Ωγ⊆Ω\Omega_\gamma \subseteq \OmegaΩγ​⊆Ω. Let Γ=∂Ωγ\Gamma = \partial\Omega_\gammaΓ=∂Ωγ​, which is a finite union of segments of length δ\deltaδ since γ\gammaγ is compact. Thus, Γ\GammaΓ is a closed, simple curve containing z1z_1z1​ and z2z_2z2​.

On the interior of Γ\GammaΓ, f(z)−wf\p{z} - wf(z)−w has only finitely many zeroes since its zeroes are isolated (fff is non-constant) and Γ\GammaΓ is compact. Hence, by shrinking δ\deltaδ if necessary, we may assume that Γ\GammaΓ contains no zeroes of f(z)−wf\p{z} - wf(z)−w. In particular, ε=inf⁡z∈Γ∣f(z)−w∣>0\epsilon = \inf_{z \in \Gamma} \abs{f\p{z} - w} > 0ε=infz∈Γ​∣f(z)−w∣>0. Since Γ\GammaΓ is compact, (local) uniform convergence gives N∈NN \in \NN∈N such that ∣fN(z)−f(z)∣<ε\abs{f_N\p{z} - f\p{z}} < \epsilon∣fN​(z)−f(z)∣<ε on Γ\GammaΓ. Thus,

∣fN(z)−f(z)∣<ε≤∣f(z)−w∣,\abs{f_N\p{z} - f\p{z}} < \epsilon \leq \abs{f\p{z} - w},∣fN​(z)−f(z)∣<ε≤∣f(z)−w∣,

so by Rouché's theorem, f(z)−wf\p{z} - wf(z)−w and (f(z)−w)+(fN(z)−f(z))=fN(z)−w\p{f\p{z} - w} + \p{f_N\p{z} - f\p{z}} = f_N\p{z} - w(f(z)−w)+(fN​(z)−f(z))=fN​(z)−w have the same number of zeroes MMM in Γ\GammaΓ. Since f(z1)=f(z2)=wf\p{z_1} = f\p{z_2} = wf(z1​)=f(z2​)=w, M≥2M \geq 2M≥2, but because fNf_NfN​ is injective, we have M≤1M \leq 1M≤1, a contradiction. Hence, fff must have been injective to begin with, which completes the proof.
